article.title: Life never goes as planned, and that's ok

text.paragraph: I went on the border trails, around Mount Gosford, which I found on All Trails. I had never been to hike in Maine or near this mountain range. It's nice because you can do a loop from where you park your car, without needing a reservation. I thought it would be easy to do: the map on All Trails said about 30 miles, which is perfect for a long day of hiking, but I found that the elevation gain was really, really, high and the trails were much longer than expected, 10 km longer. I think the maps weren't accurate for all of the switchbacks on this trail and the lack of detail. However, it was a beautiful trip with lots of wildlife and views. There is a small cliff called Cap-Frontière where there is a magnificent view of Maine with mountains, lakes and flowers like I have never seen in Quebec. The unexpectedness of this hike, i.e. the landscape and distance, make it a little bit hard and disappointing of myself, because my organisation and planning was maybe not so good in the end. Then, I remembered a book of my favorite French author and explorer, Sylvain Tesson, about the importance of “s’abandonner à vivre”.
text.citation: Il est rare en voyage de vivre des jours conformes aux idées que l’on s’étaient forgées avant les grands départs.
text.paragraph: And that is life. Things almost never goes according to the plan whether traveling or in everyday life, and I think we should accept it by changing our perspective on the course of things. Maybe we have impossible standards or we are looking for answers to unsolvable problems. In fact, it has always been like this and will always be. Therefore, I persuaded that there is an alternative by being open to everything that is surrounding us, and welcoming them as they come. But, it requires space because the more we restreint ourselves in expectations and rules, the less flexibility and curiosity you end up having towards the messiness of life. Each new experience is an opportunity to discover something new about ourselves or about the world.
